verdict.summary: UnsatisfiedDependencyException is thrown when Spring cannot resolve a dependency required by a bean — either because no matching bean exists, multiple matching beans create ambiguity, or the dependency's own creation fails.

dead_ends.action: Using @Autowired(required=false) to make the dependency optional without handling the null case
dead_ends.why_fails: Setting required=false avoids the startup exception but leaves the field null at runtime. Any code that uses the dependency without null-checking will throw NullPointerException. This trades a clear startup failure for a hidden runtime failure that is harder to diagnose.

dead_ends.action: Creating an empty stub implementation of the missing dependency just to satisfy Spring
dead_ends.why_fails: An empty stub makes the application start but provides no actual functionality. Callers of the stub get silent no-ops or null returns, which can cause data loss, incorrect behavior, or cascading failures that are much harder to debug than the original autowiring error.

workarounds.action: Read the full exception chain to identify the root cause — the actual reason is usually nested several levels deep
workarounds.how: 1. Scroll to the bottom of the exception chain (Caused by:). The root cause reveals the actual problem. 2. Common root causes: NoSuchBeanDefinitionException (bean not registered), BeanCurrentlyInCreationException (circular dependency), ClassNotFoundException (missing JAR), or a constructor/factory method throwing an exception. 3. Fix the root cause directly rather than working around the UnsatisfiedDependencyException wrapper.

workarounds.action: Use @Qualifier or @Primary to disambiguate when multiple beans of the same type exist
workarounds.how: 1. If the error mentions 'expected single matching bean but found 2', there are multiple implementations of the same interface. 2. Add @Primary to the preferred implementation to make it the default. 3. Use @Qualifier('beanName') on the injection point to specify which implementation to use. 4. Alternatively, inject List<MyInterface> to get all implementations, or use constructor injection with specific parameter names matching bean names.
workarounds.condition: when multiple beans of the same type exist

leads_to.condition: when @Autowired(required=false) is used and the null dependency is accessed at runtime
when adding a new bean to resolve the dependency creates a circular reference

preceded_by.condition: when a bean's dependency itself has a missing bean definition
when the dependency's class cannot be loaded due to classpath issues

frequently_confused_with.distinction: UnsatisfiedDependencyException wraps a deeper creation failure and points to the bean that depends on the missing/broken bean; NoSuchBeanDefinitionException directly states that no bean of the required type exists
